history.content:
Although we continue to work to resolve or improve funding issues, I have to say you should plan for them to continue indefinitely. (In the spirit of hope for the best but plan for the worst.)

Another option beyond what you describe above is to consider taking summer classes. The list of classes for Summer 2022 will be available in mid-December with enrollment beginning in early February. (And yes, Summer 2022 will be in person only as far as I now know.)

I know this isn't ideal or even possible for some students but during the summer, we have a different funding model that makes it easier to expand enrollment if waitlists grow too large (assuming there are qualified TAs available to hire). It may help relieve the stress of getting into high-demand classes during the academic year.

<md>Sophomore here. 

I've been following some of the discussions here and it seems like a lot of the CS upper divs had their enrollment numbers shrunk by a fair amount because of budget cuts, and I was wondering if these problems were brought on by covid (and therefore, will become less pronounced around sp22/fa22/sp23), or if it's only going to get worse from here?

I am specifically interested in taking CS 162, 170, and 186 (and 182 if possible) but as I am more interested in a data-oriented career, I've decided to double in ORMS & Data Science. I'm happy with my choice, but will this mean that I have little to no hope of taking the above classes without the major-enrollment-priority unless I'm a senior? If I take on the CS major (I'm aware of the GPA cap), would I have a far better time enrolling in these classes? I'm reluctant to drop one of my majors for taking those 3 classes, but they are pretty important to me, as I'd like to get some SWE-relevant skills as well (I'm guessing 170 isn't as imperative for this purpose as 162 is though). </md>
history.subject: Will the current budget/enrollment problems continue into future semesters?
